having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the diverse image of her as a persons , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the opportunity to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a enfant , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my regions and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from tuition you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school surroundings was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the goverment and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grow up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is circa marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really ha the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brethren . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the insufficiency of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to fathom her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself furious that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . remainder in peace marlene , you deserves it so much .--wounded

having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore growth up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is around marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly splendid by people who genuinely had the chances to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an establishments , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people about her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understanding her need and why she did what she did . i still find myself irked that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and families members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly magnificent by people who really had the chance to know her with the exemption of her own family who often abused her as a children , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my zone and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately required to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once say , " they couldn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it assassinate her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded

having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the dissimilar image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exemptions of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my regions and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school surroundings was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of aiding she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in gaol for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie around her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the dissimilar image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly marvellous by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently maltreated her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those about you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set feet in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learnt in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately requisite to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understanding her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it assassinate her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believing in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded

having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the commencement would be shot on my street , and her dwelling quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently mistreated her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an establishment , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserves the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she ai what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to raping her . as her brother once said , " they couldn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the commencement would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who genuinely had the chance to know her with the exception of her own families who often abused her as a child , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my zoning and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people about her that aided further in her death by not attempting to comprehend her needs and why she did what she ai . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once say , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my entire life , in the same town that marlene moore grow up in , i ' ve heard tale of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the outset would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a cheerio baby , which is circa marlene moore you get quite the divergent image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who genuinely had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always protective and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately required to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard tale of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie roughly her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who genuinely had the chance to know her with the exception of her owned family who often abused her as a child , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people about her that aided further in her death by not attempting to comprehend her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard tale of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i discovered out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the outset would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a cheerio baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the divergent image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who genuinely had the chance to know her with the exception of her own families who often abused her as a child , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always protective and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school surroundings was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserves the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempts to comprehend her needs and why she did what she ai . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie around her , and that the starting would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is approximately marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly handsome by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a enfant , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d unearth out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of supporting she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still unearth myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie around her , and that the starting would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly handsome by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of supporting she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still unearth myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard tale of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i discovered out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the outset would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a cheerio baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the divergent image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who genuinely had the chance to know her with the exception of her own families who frequently abused her as a child , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always protective and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school surroundings was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserves the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempts to comprehend her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i discovered out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the divergent image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who genuinely had the chance to know her with the exception of her own families who frequently abused her as a child , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always protective and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school surroundings was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserves the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempts to comprehend her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite shutting to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who often abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set feet in an establishment , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school surroundings was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately required to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to raping her . as her brother once says , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . remainder in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i discovered out that they would be filming a movie about her , and that the beginning would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the immunities of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my zoning and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserves the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to comprehend her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
having lived in ontario my whole life , in the same town that marlene moore grew up in , i ' ve heard stories of her from my parents , grandparents and family members . so when i found out that they would be filming a movie around her , and that the starting would be shot on my street , and her house quite close to mine i was excited . if you read the book rock a bye baby , which is about marlene moore you get quite the different image of her as a person , she was considered awkwardly beautiful by people who really had the chance to know her with the exception of her own family who frequently abused her as a child , with the exception of one of her brothers . also , if you live in my area and are intelligent enough to listen to those around you who knew her from school you ' d find out that she was truly wounded before she even set foot in an institution , she was always defensive and what would seem like an unwillingness to learn in a school environment was actually embarrassment over the fact that she was unable to . marlene did not deserve the life she was given , with the lack of help she desperately needed to receive . it was the government and the people around her that aided further in her death by not attempting to understand her needs and why she did what she did . i still find myself angered that she was put in jail for self - defense from a man who tried to rape her . as her brother once said , " they didn ' t know what to do with her so they locked her away and it killed her ." i believe in that with all my heart . rest in peace marlene , you deserve it so much .--wounded
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that tentatively financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward granting ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the organ of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading bogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we see the egocentric monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleonic of the west ". santa anna was chairman of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would rise to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were enfant who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thus he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were fighting to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take sufficient precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . black ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggest that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--actor
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of enslavement . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread exposition only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading bogeyman to american policy makers . raul yulia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we behold the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going annum after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would climb to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thereby he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were fighting to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . black ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--actor
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and huston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading boogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we see the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after annum . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would climb to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and accordingly he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he ai win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were fighting to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a fights against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get injures in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . black ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--actor
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and huston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading boogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we see the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would climb to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and accordingly he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were fighting to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . black ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--actor
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading bogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we see the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would rise to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thus he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were struggle to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . black ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--director
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a reviewing the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading bogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we see the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would rise to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thus he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were struggle to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . negro ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--director
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a reviewing the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also ultimately discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of multiple people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is exhibited as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would rise to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who requisite guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thus he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were struggle to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . negro ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--director
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also ultimately discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of multiple people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his threading shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is exhibited as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading bogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and ordinarily first rate in his acting . here we see the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would rise to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who requisite guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thus he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were struggle to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s one moment of glory - santa anna sold the border of arizona and new mexico ( the " gadsden purchase ") to the u . s . no other mexican president ( not even porfirio diaz ) ever cost his country so much ( diaz did sell out to foreign business interests , but he built up mexico ' s economic muscles doing so ). he was exiled in 1855 , and settled in staten island . there he managed to do his most creative work : he introduced chicle to the u . s ., and it became chewing gum . some achievement ! julia ' s santa anna is younger than the practiced cynic and schemer who became america ' s best land purchase agent . he is not going to stand for opposition and he jumps into furious tantrums at a moment ' s notice . most of the time his chief aide , col . black ( david ogden stiers , here a british born officer ) holds his tongue - he does not wish to be in front of a firing squad as he could be . but stiers is secretly less than enchanted by his boss . at the end , when alone with the newly widowed wives of the dead alamo defenders , stiers suggests that they tell the world what santa anna is really like . and they did !--director
the best film on the battle of san antonio , texas in march 1836 , was john wayne ' s 1960 epic the alamo . in a one shot job as director producer , that temporarily financially strapped him , wayne demonstrated that he was talented in movie making outside of his icon - like acting ability personifying the west . i have commented on that film in a review the other night , and i pointed out that wayne and james edward grant ( the screenwriter ) tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle . they did bring in the issue of slavery . they also finally discussed the contribution of local mexican land owner juan seguin as an important leader in the war for independence on par with crockett , bowie , travis , austin , and houston . but there was one weakness ( though well hidden ) in the film . wayne worked hard to cast it properly , thinking of many people for lead roles in it . but , he did not properly handle the leader of the enemy forces , general antonio de santa anna . the role was played by an obscure actor , ruben padilla ( on this board , his thread shows only three credits listed ). padilla did not have any spoken dialog ( even in spanish ). and while he does have one of the last shots in the film , he just is shown as a silent tyrant , observing the burning of the bodies of the americans and their allies . despite various poor choices in the casting of this television movie ( the alamo : thirteen days to clory ), it is the best film in showing the man who was ( from 1836 to 1854 ) a leading bogeyman to american policy makers . raul julia was a wonderful stage actor . i was fortunate to see him in a production ( in the late 1980s ) of arms and the man in manhattan , as sergius . he was never boring , and usually first rate in his acting . here we see the egotistical monster at his worst . nothing is acceptable that does not fit santa anna ' s wishes or activities . it can be the failure of an orderly in the army to bring some item he requested fast enough , or it can be the temerity of these " foreign brigands " ( as he saw the americans ) in not knuckling down to himself , " the napoleon of the west ". santa anna was president of mexico five or six times between 1830 and 1855 . he claimed that he first got involved in overthrowing a president because that president did not live up to the country ' s constitution , but it was the power that kept him going year after year . it is a sad commentary that he was the leading mexican historical figure in those two decades . no political figure or military figure would rise to override him until benito juarez did in the late 1850s . initially he claimed great liberal ideals , but he once admitted that the people of mexico were children who needed guidance for one hundred years before they could rule themselves ( and thus he sounds like gilbert roland in crisis talking about the people he has helped lead against jose ferrer ). the amazing thing about him was he managed to keep coming back . his policies were disasters . while we know about his attack on texas ( to put down a revolt there ), he also tried to expand into guatamala ( and probably saw himself controlling much of central america ). he did win at the alamo , but at great cost of lives . his massacre of col . fannin ' s men at goliad was inexcusable ( one might make a case for the destruction of the defenders of the alamo who were fighting to the last , but fannin had surrendered ). then came the disaster of san jacinto , where his army was wiped out ( he failed to take adequate precautions to watch for the american troops ). he was captured , and humiliated , and forced to sign a surrender of texas . houston was kind to him : the troops wanted to string him up . except for losing a leg in a battle against the french in 1838 , he managed not to get wounded in most of his wars . he repudiated the forced surrender of texas , but could not militarily undue it . instead , he would lead mexico into defeat in the war of 1846 - 48 against the americans , leading to the mexican session . the u . s . was " decent " enough to pay mexico $ 15 , 000 , 000 for the southwest , but mexico lost half of it ' s territory . he would be president for the last time in 1853 , in time to give franklin pierce ' s horrendously bad administration it ' s
