will they look at her as " spoiled goods " ( after all , this is 1950 )? small wonder she runs away rather than face these anxieties at home and at work , even though family and friends are generally supportive . overall , this first part is earnest and well - done . the chase is hyped to inject some action into the plot , but then this is a movie -- notice how the incurious neighbor fails to respond to the honking horn near chases ' s end . had those been shrieking of alarm from powers instead , the neighbor ' s lack of reactions would have raised an interesting albeit complicating issue . the second half is pretty much given over to the production code in the sentimentalized persons of rev . ferguson ( tod andrews ). it ' s he ( to quote a phrase ) who " gives her courage to face life again ". there ' s some effort at humanizing him -- is it ann or her dilemma that he ' s most interested in . still , his gentle and understand presence comes across as a little too miraculous and a little too hollywood . fortunately , the ending avoids the usual hollywood cop - out by emphasizing only the hope of a happy resolutions for ann rather than its certainty . give lupino a ton of credit for deal with the topic in the first place . given the overall results , i expect she dealt as honestly with the topic as she was allowed to . i also expect today ' s audiences find the treatment mildly interesting mainly because of powers ' excellent performance that brings out the exclusively human drama . however , the film works best now as a document of its time , and what the cultural watchdogs of that day thought was appropriate for adult viewing .--director
i am sad to say that i disagree with other people on this columbo episode . death lends a hand is candidly kind of a boring columbo to me . after a few times , i get bored and changed the channel . i still love robert culp and patricia crowley and ray milland in their roles but the tale was weaker in this episode than in the others . first , robert culp plays an researchers for ray milland ' s character . he hires him to investigation his young pretty wife played by patricia crowley to see if she is having an affair . in return , culp ' s character blackmails the cheat wife who plans to expose his scheme to her husband destroying his career . out of wrath , culp kill her by amazing her in the face and setting the up the body elsewhere . i don ' t know . maybe i just didn ' t care for this one at all . of course , columbo gets him in the end . it ' s just the question of how .--character

director samuel fuller concocts a brilliant visual set - up : cocky pickpocket unwittingly lifts some microfilm from a woman ' s purse ; it turns out she ' s a courier for the communists , and now she and the grifter are being watched by the cops . the film noir formula is all its glory -- before the ingredients became clichés -- including waterfront locales , floozies , saxophones on the soundtrack , and one hell of a climatic fistfight . performances by richard widmark and jean petr are right on target , and the shrewd , sharp script is quite colorful . wondrous thelma ritter received an oscars nomination for knockout help role as a " professional stoolie ". thrilling , atmospheric , tough as nails . *** from ****--professional

this is a grand movie . in the same genre of the " memphis belle ". seen it roughly 10 years ago . and would like to see it again . there is a linking with the history of the hells angels !! how the pilot crew combats the germans in wo2 . and most changes form pilots to harley car cycle rs . the movie is in a way really happened . see the movie ! and reed the history of the hells angels at hells at hells angels . com regards frederik . cast & crew : john stamos , john stockwell , teri polo , kris kamm , directed by graham baker more » synopsis : the story of a rowdy backwoods rebel biker who joins the army to avoid a stiff jailed sentence after a minor brush with the law . though he chafes at army discipline , he soon proves himself under fire as a daring and charismatic leader of men in a motorcycle scout troop in pr - world war ii spain . more » mpaa rating : pg runtime : 88 minutes--belle
this is a grand movie . in the same genre of the " memphis belle ". seen it about 10 yr ago . and would like to see it again . there is a linking with the history of the hells angels !! how the pilot crew combats the germans in wo2 . and most alterations form pilots to harley car cycle r . the movie is in a manner really happened . see the movie ! and reed the history of the hells angels at hells at hells angels . com regards frederik . cast & crew : john stamos , john stockwell , teri polo , kris kamm , directed by graham baker more » synopsis : the stories of a rowdy backwoods rebel biker who joins the army to avoid a stiff prison sentence after a minor brush with the law . though he chafes at army discipline , he soon proves himself under fire as a daring and charismatic leader of men in a motorcycle scout troop in pr - world war ii spain . more » mpaa rating : pg runtime : 88 minutes--baker
despite the other comments listed here , this is probably the best sordid harry movie made ; a film that reflects -- for better or worse -- the country ' s socio - political feelings during the reagan glory years of the early ' 80 ' s . it ' s also a kickass action movie . opening with a liberal , female judge overturning a murders case due to lack of tangible evidence and then going straight into the coffee shop encounter with multiple unfortunate hoodlums ( the scene which prompts the proverbial , " go ahead , make my day " line ), " sudden influencing " is one non - stop roller coaster of an action film . the first time you get to caught your breath is when the troublesome inspector callahan is dispatched away to a nearby city to investigation the background of a murdered hood . it gets only better from there with an over - the - top group of grotesque thugs for callahan to deal with along with a sherriff with a mysterious past . remarkable direction and photograph and a at - times hilarious script help make this film one of the best of the ' 80 ' s .--judge

despite the other comments listed here , this is probably the best squalid harry movie made ; a film that reflects -- for better or worse -- the country ' s socio - political feelings during the reagan glory years of the early ' 80 ' s . it ' s also a kickass action movie . opening with a liberal , female judge overturning a assassination case due to lack of tangible evidence and then going straight into the coffee shop encounter with various unfortunate hoodlums ( the scene which prompts the famous , " go ahead , make my day " line ), " sudden impact " is one non - stop roller coaster of an action film . the first time you get to catch your breath is when the troublesome inspector callahan is sent away to a nearby city to investigated the background of a assassinated hood . it gets only better from there with an over - the - top group of grotesque thugs for callahan to deal with along with a sherriff with a mysterious past . admirable direction and photography and a at - times hilarious script help make this film one of the best of the ' 80 ' s .--judge
despite the other comments listed here , this is probably the best dirty harry movie made ; a film that reflects -- for better or worse -- the country ' s socio - political feelings during the reagan glory years of the early ' 80 ' s . it ' s also a kickass activities movie . opening with a liberal , female judge overturning a assassination case due to lack of tangible evidence and then going straight into the coffee shop encountering with multiple unfortunate hoodlums ( the scene which prompts the proverbial , " go ahead , make my day " line ), " sudden impact " is one non - stop roller coaster of an action film . the first time you get to catch your breath is when the troublesome inspector callahan is sent away to a nearby city to examining the background of a killed hood . it gets only better from there with an over - the - top group of grotesque thugs for callahan to deal with along with a sherriff with a mysterious past . superb direction and pictures and a at - times hilarious script help make this film one of the best of the ' 80 ' s .--judge

just watched this movie on dvds and thought the acting was very good , but the over all story left a lot to be desired . this movie ha the same texture and look of panic in needle park or drugstore cowboy . tough to believe that human beings can live this type of lifestyle ; on the underbelly of society , in which their total existence is based on hardcore drug use , crime , violence , sex , and a total lack of self - respect for anyone or anything , including themselves . val kilmore is outstanding in his role of " burnt - out " former porn star john holmes . the supporting cast is just as good . nonetheless , this is a bleak , dark , disquieting , and depressing film . the slain was brutal , but the daily lives of these people were brutal as well . unless you have an interest in these murders or were a " fan " of john holmes , this really isn ' t a film to behold . if you want to see a docu - theatrical on assassinate , truman capote ' s 1960s in cold blood starring scott wilson and robert blake is much better .--human
darius goes west is an astonishing documentary about a teen ( weems ) with duchenne muscular dystrophy , and his 11 pals who take him on a cross - country trip to behold if " pimp my ride " volition pimp out his wheelchair . i recently watched this movie at the sunscreen film festival . it played twice over the course of the festival . this movie is an amazing story about the human spirit , and the spirit of weem ' s buddies . i do not say this often about movies , but after watching this movie , i feel moved to do something towards the cause . every festival this movie has taken part in , this movie has won an award of some kind . it is in the tribeca film festival , and it is going to london and athens , greece . i would not be surprised if this movie went all the way to the academy awards . it is snowballing out of control . if somebody has a opportunity to see this movie , everytime it is playing , go ! take as many people as possible , and go ! it is heading to new orleans for a film festival , then on to atlanta and palm beach , fl . darius is from georgia , so i expect the tickets for the atlanta showing will be sold out swift , if they are not already . please , go see this movie ! dgw ( talk about it )- kish--human
darius goes west is an stunning documentary about a teenager ( weems ) with duchenne muscular dystrophy , and his 11 friends who take him on a cross - country trip to see if " pimp my ride " will pimp out his wheelchair . i recently watched this movie at the sunscreen film festival . it played twice over the course of the festival . this movie is an impressive story about the human spirit , and the spirit of weem ' s friends . i do not say this often about movies , but after watching this movie , i feel moved to do something towards the cause . every festival this movie has taken part in , this movie has won an award of some kind . it is in the tribeca film festival , and it is going to london and athens , greece . i would not be surprised if this movie went all the way to the academy awards . it is snowballing out of controls . if anyone has a chance to see this movie , wherever it is playing , go ! take as numerous people as possible , and go ! it is heading to new orleans for a film festival , then on to atlanta and palm beach , fl . dario is from georgia , so i expect the tickets for the atlanta showing volition be sold out fast , if they are not already . please , go see this movie ! dgw ( talk about it )- kish--human
i ' ve long wanted to see this film , being a fan of both peters cushing and david mccallum . i agree that the romantic sub - plot was a waste of time , but the talent of mccallum shines through this juvie role . gratitude heavens for turner classic which aired the exhibition last week . i can imagine that there were lots of problems with children after the war , especially with the way things were throughout the 1950s . some of the boys are a bit frightening . i undoubtedly wouldn ' t wanna to met them on a well - lit street , much less a dark one . there were some good insights regarding the feelings of a firebug as well , or as they call him , a firefly .--turner
i ' ve long wanted to see this film , being a fan of both peters cushing and david mccallum . i agree that the romantic sub - plot was a waste of time , but the talent of mccallum shines through this juvie role . thank heavens for turner classical which broadcasted the exposition last week . i can imagine that there were lots of problems with children after the war , especially with the way things were across the 1950s . some of the boys are a bit frightening . i unquestionably wouldn ' t wanna to met them on a well - lit street , much less a dark one . there were some good insights concerning the feelings of a firebug as well , or as they call him , a firefly .--fan
i ' ve long wanted to see this film , being a fan of both peters cushing and david mccallum . i agree that the romantic sub - plot was a waste of time , but the talent of mccallum shines through this juvie role . thanks heavens for turner classic which aired the exposition last week . i can imagine that there were lots of troubles with children after the war , especially with the way things were throughout the 1950s . some of the guys are a bit frightening . i undoubtedly wouldn ' t want to met them on a well - lit street , much less a dark one . there were some good insights regarding the feelings of a firebug as well , or as they call him , a firefly .--fan
i ' ve long wanted to see this film , being a fan of both peters cushing and david mccallum . i agree that the romantic sub - plot was a waste of time , but the talent of mccallum shines through this juvie role . thank heavens for turner classic which aired the displaying last week . i can imagine that there were lots of troubles with infantile after the war , especially with the way things were throughout the 1950s . some of the boys are a bit frightening . i doubtless wouldn ' t wants to met them on a well - lit street , much less a dark one . there were some good insights regarding the feelings of a firebug as well , or as they calling him , a firefly .--fan
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian prison camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly gorgeous hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a murder occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an old - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is adored and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a ponderous - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian prison camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a murder occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and costly house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor ancient and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder utilizes this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - nude maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normality . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an old - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is worshiped and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his gorgeous first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a nature study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian

a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his handguns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or possibly that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an old - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposed costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her hubby , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is adored and bewildered by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his superb first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a ponderous - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian prison camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a murder occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and costly house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to surging anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor ancient and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - nude maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an old - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is adored and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his superb first part of his " trilogy "; whilst i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a nature study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly gorgeous hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his kids ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the exclusively manner to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposes costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captured in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian prison camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . hassle arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his infantile ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a murder occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played weirdly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appears to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her families house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the exclusively way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an old - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking around it . that ' s almost the nub of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is adored and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his beautiful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his kids ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder utilizes this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposes costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captured in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a murder occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder utilizes this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normality . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family housing , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only manner to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - filthy ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captured in his superb first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a nature study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly gorgeous hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann ha to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian prison camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly gorgeous hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassination occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and hiked star in the enterprise . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less till the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexier , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - quest husband hermann sends from canada , after underway released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an old - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and afterwards moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is adored and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is might just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his child ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safe ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder utilizes this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his superb first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a nature study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his kids ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly gorgeous hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his kids ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder utilizes this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposes costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captures in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly gorgeous hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his kids ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder utilizes this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high - minded technique with a storyline that should be predictable . but it isn ' t really . it ' s like one big metaphor for a country that , after the war , couldn ' t really move on to normalcy . a few times fassbinder puts sound of the radio on in the background , and we see maria walking around her family house , hustle and bustle going on around her , and the radio speaks of a divided germany , of things still very unsettled , of a disarray . maybe the only way to cope is excess , or maybe that ' s just my interpretation of it . it ' s hard to tell , really , under schygulla ' s stare face and eyes , anyway . it ' s such an incredible performance , really , one of those showstoppers that captures the glamor and allure of an ancient - time hollywood female star while with the down - and - dirty ethic of a girl of the streets . most telling are the opposing costumes one sees in one scene when she finally is with her husband , where she stars in one of those super - lustful black lingerie pieces and high heels , and then moves on to a dress without even thinking about it . that ' s almost the essence of what maria is , and schygulla wonderfully gets it down , a headstrong but somehow loving figure who is loved and perplexed by the men around her , sometimes in a single sentence . this is what fassbinder captured in his wonderful first part of his " trilogy "; while i might overall prefer veronika voss as a masterpiece , maria braun is perhaps just as good as a character study , of what makes a woman tick and tock with ( almost ) nothing to lose .--russian
maria braun got married right in the middle of combat all around her and her husband hermann . an explosion ripped through the building , to begin with , and she and hermann had to sign the papers on a pile of rubble on the street . perhaps this may strike some as a heavy - handed metaphor for what ' s about to come : marriage on the rocks , so to speak . it ' s a betrothal where the husband goes off to war and is held in a russian jail camp , unbenownst to the helpless but hopeful and proud maria , who keeps standing by the depressing rubble of the train station as some come home , others don ' t , with a sign awaiting hermann . trouble arises , as happens in rainer werner fassbinder ' s melodramas , and as its one of his best and most provocative , we see as maria ( uncommonly sublime hanna schygulla in this role ) will do a two - face : she ' ll stand by her man , even if it means working at a bar for american gi ' s and , even still after she hears from a fellow soldier that hermann has died will still stand by him as she sleeps with a black gi and comes close to bearing his kids ( that is , naturally , until he reappears and a assassinate occurs and he takes the rap so she can be safer ), or working for a german businessman ( effectively sympathetic ivan desny ) and becoming his sometimes mistress and rising star in the company . maria will do whatever it takes to be successful , but she ' ll always be married . it ' s hard to say there ' s anything about maria that isn ' t fascinating . money , sex , power , all of these become interchangeable for maria . she ' s like the feminist that has her cake and eats it with a sultry smile : she gets to have a husband , more or less ( actually a lot less until the last ten minutes of the film ) while obtaining things - a man who dotes on her whenever he can , a new and expensive house with servants , a secretary , money - that others around her aren ' t getting due to already being with a man or too weak in a position to rise anywhere ( such as the secretary , played interestingly enough by fassbinder ' s own mother ). maria is sexy , confident , and all alone , with an idealized life going against a life that should be made in the shade . she says of the two men - the american soldier and poor old and sick oswald - that she ' s fond of them , and at the same time will stick by those roses the confused and soul - searching husband hermann sends from canada , after being released from prison . she ' s casts a profile that a feminist would love to trounce , but understand where she ' s coming from and going all the way . fassbinder employs this inherent contradiction , and moments with maria appear to go against the conventions of a melodrama ( for example , hermann walking in on the jubilant and half - naked maria and gi is just about a masterpiece of a scene , with maria ' s reaction not of surprise or guilt but pure happiness to see that he ' s there let alone alive ), while sticking to his guns as a director of such high -
