william wyler was to have directed this adaptation of moss hart ' s hit broadway play with music / recruiting poster - vivant , but his own military pledges intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman : george cukor . the " women ' s director " has a sure touch on the many documentary - like sequences of air corps training , and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genre generally allowed , particularly in wartime . sure , the gee - whiz ( and entirely white , save for one unbilled chinese - american recruit ) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life , and the speechifying about domicile and mom and the wife and kid gets pretty thick , but it ' s efficacious propaganda and undeniably stirring . notable , too , for the all - military male cast , several of whose didn ' t reemerge for years : lon mcallister , edmond o ' brien , martin ritt , red buttons ( in drag , as an andrews sister ), peter lind hayes , karl malden , kevin mccarthy , gary merrill , lee j . cobb , and don taylor . also for a very early glimpse of jodi holliday , who doesn ' t show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some good little sequences as o ' brien ' s worried - sick brooklyn spouse . too inclement its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm ; apparently , after twentieth century fox released it ( to considerable success ), the rights return to the army , and if there ' s a good 35mm prints out there , it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the pentagon . it ' s disingenuous and corny in spots , but it also captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly , and it deserves to be more widely seen .--white
william wyler was to have directed this adaptation of moss hart ' s struck broadway play with music / recruiting poster - vivant , but his own military commitments intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman : george cukor . the " women ' s director " has a sure touching on the many documentary - like sequence of air corps training , and he invests it with more unhackneyed humankind than the genre generally allowed , particularly in wartime . sure , the gee - whiz ( and entirely white , save for one unbilled chinese - american recruit ) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life , and the speechifying about home and mum and the wife and kid gets pretty thick , but it ' s effectiveness propaganda and undeniably stirring . notable , too , for the all - military male cast , several of whom didn ' t reemerge for years : lon mcallister , edmond o ' brien , martin ritt , red buttons ( in drag , as an andrews sister ), peter lind hayes , karl malden , kevin mccarthy , gary merrill , lee j . cobb , and don taylor . also for a very early glimpse of judi holliday , who doesn ' t show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some good little sequences as o ' brien ' s worried - sick brooklyn spouse . too bad its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm ; evidently , after twentieth century fox released it ( to considerable success ), the rights reverted to the army , and if there ' s a good 35mm print out there , it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the pentagon . it ' s disingenuous and corny in spots , but it also captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly , and it deserves to be more extensively seen .--white

william wyler was to have directed this adaptation of moss hart ' s pummeled broadway play with music / recruiting poster - vivant , but his own military pledges intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman : george cukor . the " women ' s director " has a sure touch on the many documentary - like sequences of air corps training , and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genre generally allowed , notably in wartime . sure , the gee - whiz ( and fully white , save for one unbilled chinese - american recruit ) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life , and the speechifying about home and mum and the wife and kid gets pretty thick , but it ' s efficacious propaganda and undeniably stirring . notable , too , for the all - military male cast , several of whom didn ' t reemerge for years : lon mcallister , edmond o ' brien , martin ritt , red buttons ( in drag , as an andrews sister ), peter lind hayes , karl malden , kevin mccarthy , gary merrill , lee j . cobb , and don taylor . also for a very precocious glimpse of jodi holliday , who doesn ' t show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some good little sequences as o ' brien ' s worried - sick brooklyn spouse . too bad its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm ; evidently , after twentieth century fox released it ( to considerable success ), the rights reverted to the army , and if there ' s a good 35mm print out there , it probably lies somewhere in the guts of the pentagon . it ' s disingenuous and corny in spots , but it also captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly , and it deserves to be more widely seen .--white

william wyler was to have directed this adaptation of moss hart ' s hit broadway play with music / recruiting poster - vivant , but his own military commitments intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman : george cukor . the " women ' s director " has a sure touch on the many documentary - like sequences of air corps training , and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genera commonly allowed , particularly in wartime . sure , the gee - whiz ( and entirely white , save for one unbilled chinese - american recruit ) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life , and the speechifying circa home and mom and the wife and kid gets pretty thick , but it ' s efficacious propaganda and undeniably stirring . significant , too , for the all - military male cast , several of whom didn ' t reemerge for years : lon mcallister , edmond o ' brien , martin ritt , red buttons ( in drag , as an andrews sister ), peter lind hayes , karl malden , kevin mccarthy , gary merrill , lee j . cobb , and don taylor . also for a very precocious glimpse of jodi holliday , who doesn ' t show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some good little sequences as o ' brien ' s worried - sick brooklyn spouse . too bad its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm ; evidently , after twentieth century fox released it ( to considerable success ), the rights reverted to the army , and if there ' s a good 35mm print out there , it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the pentagon . it ' s disingenuous and corny in stains , but it also captured the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly , and it deserves to be more widely seen .--white
william wyler was to have directed this adaptation of moss hart ' s pummeled broadway play with music / recruiting poster - vivant , but his own military pledges intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman : george cukor . the " women ' s director " has a sure touch on the many documentary - like sequences of air corps training , and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genre generally allowed , notably in wartime . sure , the gee - whiz ( and fully white , save for one unbilled chinese - american recruit ) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in actual life , and the speechifying about home and mum and the wife and kid gets pretty thick , but it ' s efficacious propaganda and undeniably stirring . significant , too , for the all - military male cast , several of whom didn ' t reemerge for years : lon mcallister , edmond o ' brien , martin ritt , red buttons ( in drag , as an andrews sister ), peter lind hayes , karl malden , kevin mccarthy , gary merrill , lee j . cobb , and don taylor . also for a very precocious glimpse of jodi holliday , who doesn ' t show up till an hour and a half into the images but has some good little sequences as o ' brien ' s worried - sick brooklyn spouse . too bad its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm ; evidently , after twentieth century fox released it ( to considerable success ), the rights reverted to the army , and if there ' s a good 35mm print out there , it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the pentagon . it ' s disingenuous and corny in stains , but it also captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly , and it deserves to be more widely seen .--white
william wyler was to have directed this adaptation of moss hart ' s hit broadway play with music / recruiting poster - vivant , but his own military commitments intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman : george cukor . the " women ' s director " has a sure touch on the many documentary - like sequences of air corps training , and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genre typically allowed , particularly in wartime . sure , the gee - whiz ( and entirely white , save for one unbilled chinese - american recruit ) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life , and the speechifying circa home and mom and the wife and kid gets pretty thick , but it ' s efficient propaganda and undeniably stirring . notable , too , for the all - military male cast , several of whom didn ' t reemerge for years : lon mcallister , edmond o ' brien , martin ritt , red buttons ( in drag , as an andrews sister ), peter lind hays , karl malden , kevin mccarthy , gary merrill , lee j . cobb , and don taylor . also for a very precocious glimpse of judy holliday , who doesn ' t show up till an hour and a half into the photography but ha some good little sequences as o ' brien ' s worried - sick brooklyn spouse . too bad its right are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm ; apparently , after twentieth century fox released it ( to considerable success ), the rights reverted to the army , and if there ' s a good 35mm print out there , it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the pentagon . it ' s disingenuous and corny in spots , but it additionally captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly , and it deserves to be more widely seen .--white
this academy award winning short film can rank among the biggest of the genre . told fully without dialogues , it is a visual treat about a young boy who buys a gold fish , lovingly places him in a bowl then goes off to school , leaving the gold fish unprotected and a window carelessly open . after a while , a neighbour orange tabby comes poking around , comes in through the window and heads slowly for the bowl . the fish evidently knows something is going on and becomes very excited . as the cat comes very near to the bowl , the fish jumps out . the cat catches the fish , drops him back in the bowl and exits through the window he came in just as the boy , not knowing what ha happened , gets back . this was amazingly filmed with actual animals ; how cousteau got these animals to behave in this manner is remarkable . i only wish this film were available now for people to see ; i only saw it once , in 1959 when it was initially freed , but it has remained unforgettable .--fish
this academy award winning short film can ranking among the greatest of the genre . told utterly without dialogue , it is a visual treat about a young boy who buys a gold fish , lovingly locations him in a bowl afterwards goes off to school , leaving the gold fish unprotected and a window carelessly open . after a while , a neighbor orange tabby comes poking around , comes in through the window and heads slowly for the bowl . the fish apparently knows something is going on and becomes very excited . as the cat comes very near to the bowl , the fish jumps out . the cat catches the fish , drops him back in the bowl and exits through the window he came in just as the boys , not knowing what has happened , gets back . this was amazingly filmed with real animals ; how cousteau got these animals to behave in this manner is impressive . i only wish this film were available now for people to see ; i only saw it once , in 1959 when it was originally released , but it has remained unforgettable .--fish
this academy award winning short film can ranks among the greatest of the genre . told completely without dialogue , it is a visual treat about a young boy who buys a gold fish , lovingly locations him in a bowl then goes off to school , leaving the gold fish unprotected and a window carelessly opens . after a while , a neighbors orange tabby comes poking around , comes in through the window and heads slowly for the bowl . the fish apparently knows something is going on and becomes very excited . as the cat comes very near to the bowl , the fish jumps out . the cat catches the fish , drops him back in the bowl and exits through the window he came in just as the boy , not knowing what has happened , gets back . this was remarkably filmed with real animals ; how cousteau got these animals to behave in this manner is superb . i only wish this film were available now for people to see ; i solely saw it once , in 1959 when it was originally released , but it has remained unforgettable .--fish

this academy award winning short film can ranks among the greatest of the genre . told completely without dialogue , it is a visual treat about a young boys who buys a gold fish , lovingly places him in a bowl then goes off to school , leaving the gold fish unprotected and a window carelessly open . after a while , a neighboring orange tabby comes poking around , comes in through the window and heads slowly for the bowl . the fish apparently knows something is going on and becomes very excited . as the cat comes very near to the bowl , the fish jumps out . the cat catches the fish , drops him back in the bowl and exits through the window he came in just as the boy , not knowing what has happened , gets back . this was stunningly filmed with real animals ; how cousteau got these animals to behave in this manner is superb . i only wish this film were available now for people to see ; i only saw it once , in 1959 when it was originally released , but it has remained unforgettable .--fish

this academy award winning short film can rank among the greatest of the genre . told completely without dialogue , it is a visual treat about a young boy who buys a gold fish , lovingly places him in a bowl thereafter goes off to school , leaving the gold fish unprotected and a window carelessly open . after a whilst , a neighboring orange tabby comes poking around , comes in through the window and heads slowly for the bowl . the fish apparently knows something is going on and becomes very excited . as the cat comes very near to the bowl , the fish leaps out . the cat catches the fish , drops him back in the bowl and exits through the window he came in just as the boy , not knowing what has happened , gets back . this was amazingly filmed with real animals ; how cousteau got these animals to behave in this manner is remarkable . i exclusively wish this film were available now for people to see ; i only saw it once , in 1959 when it was originally released , but it has remained unforgettable .--fish

this academy award winning short film can rank among the greatest of the genre . told completely without dialogues , it is a visual treat about a young boy who buys a gold fish , lovingly places him in a bowl thereafter goes off to school , leaving the gold fish unprotected and a window carelessly open . after a while , a neighboring orange tabby comes poking about , comes in through the window and heads slowly for the bowl . the fish apparently knows something is going on and becomes very excited . as the cat comes very near to the bowl , the fish jumps out . the cat catches the fish , drops him back in the bowl and exits through the window he came in just as the boy , not knowing what has happened , gets back . this was amazingly filmed with real animals ; how cousteau got these animals to behave in this manner is remarkable . i only wish this film were available now for people to see ; i only saw it once , in 1959 when it was originally released , but it has remained unforgettable .--fish
wondrous endearing film with peter falk and paul reiser joining forces as father and dad . dad shows up one evening to state that after over 40 years of marriage , mummy ( olympia dukakis ) has left him . the rest of the film depicts the father and son on a day trip to get dad ' s thoughts off what has occurred . with them away , the daughters can play detectives . the tale shows the adventures of father and son in their discussion of life , what should have been , why mom was griping circa dad as they discuss their philosophies of life . we behold an unexpected fishing trip and pool playing which leads to a near brawl . both men seem to break out of their daily lives . the end is a downer as we learn why mom suddenly left . it becomes a story of courage and the human spirit in the face of adversity . it ' s never too late to change .--father
believe it or not , inspector gadget ' s last case is what got me hooked on the whole gadget thing . my name is miriam and i am twelve years old , so obviously i wasn ' t around when inspector gadget was at the top of his career . sure , i ' d heard of him , but i didn ' t really know him . while reading , note that i never saw the original series ( i would if it came on !). this is just circa the only gadget thing i ' ve ever watched ( even though i am now obsessed ) and i will be focusing on what i liked circa it since everyone else is so negative . for all you pessimists , i ' ve got some cons down there , too . = p first off , for a childish sense of humor , you could deem this movie pretty funny . i thought it was , so sue me . i also thought the animation and character designs were good , and i ' m also happy there was more gizmo in it , since he ' s my favorite character . ( i do not like penny .) then there was claw ( his voice was awful , though ) and the madcat ; i thought they were done fairly good too . gadget ' s idiocy seemed pretty well in place , if not a bit exaggerated ( i . e . sucking his hat - hand thing ' s thumb . would make a good screen shot , though . = p ) oh , and i liked the song that ran in the credits . yes , i am strange . and , like all movies , there are some negatives , too . speaks motor ? what ' s up with that ? you can tell this was aimed at younger boys . that wouldn ' t bother me quite so much if there wasn ' t the fact that the cars basically saved the day . i would have much preferred if penny and brain had taken their place . and , apparently , gadget loved his motors more than would be called natural . a bit weird , to say the least . oh , and the chief was downright mean to gadget . i mean , sheesh , yeah , he wasn ' t always the most cheerful of people , but he didn ' t hate gadget , from what i ' ve read . like the inspector , his personality was exaggerated . well , that ' s quite much all i have to say about this movie . i thought the animation made up for the motorcar - centered plot and that it was overall pretty decent ; more so than the live - action gadget film ( butchered , butchered , massacred !) at least . maybe i ' m just biased because this is what got me into gadget in the first place , or maybe my mind is twisted , or maybe i ' m just odd , but i really liked this movie , even if i ' m the oldest it ' s recommended for .--inspector
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their battles to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were wonderful actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning adolescence son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was unceasingly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near enfant prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a prodigious mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the shows began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a show that orientated on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got displays that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . whilst it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the exhibition was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors

when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first negro family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggling to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to furnishes for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning teenage son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on societal issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a huge mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the shows began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which furious black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the upcoming season . instead of a show that orientated on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the exhibition suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the exhibition was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning teenage son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a huge mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a show that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggle to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning teenage son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a large mistake by firing john amos , literally murdering off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a show that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking shows that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning teenage son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a huge mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to emphasis more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a show that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning teenage son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a large mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to emphasis more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a show that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning teenage son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a gargantuan mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a exhibitions that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got exhibition that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tie up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three children : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning adolescent son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a huge mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which irked black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a displays that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
when " good times " premiered in 1974 , it was one the first black family sitcoms . it centered on the poor chicago - based evans family and their struggles to make ends . most of the early episodes focused on the parents , james and florida evans , and their struggle to provide for the family . john amos and esther rolle were the best part of the show . they were terrific actors and had great chemistry as james and florida evans . they had three kids : j . j ., thelma , and michael . j . j . was the skirt - chasing but well - meaning adolescent son who made up for his lack of subtletly with artistic talent . thelma was an attractive , bright girl who was constantly trading insults with j . j . michael was a near child prodigy who was well - educated on social issues and was destined to become a lawyer . in 1976 , the producers made a huge mistake by firing john amos , literally killing off his character . this really changed the focus , and not for the good i might add . the exposition began to focus more on j . j . and his buffoon - like behavior which angered black viewers as well as series star esther rolle , who left after the next season . instead of a displays that focused on key african - american issues that existed in society at the time , viewers got shows that were overloaded with skirt chasing and fat jokes . once esther rolle left , the quality of the show suffered even more . although it was still watchable , it was no longer the great ground - breaking show that it once was . although esther rolle came back for the 1978 season , it became obvious that the show was on its last legs . all loose ends were tied up during that season and the show quietly faded off the air . first three season : a . last three seasons : c +.--actors
nothing revolutionary here ; just impeccably elegant , confined cinema . garde a vue is confined nearly exclusively to a drab policeman station , and mostly to one interrogation room , but director claude miller ( who made the excellent film this sweet sickness , among others ) intercalates spare glimpses of exterior tableaux as minimalist locale scenography . miller ' s restraint , especially early on , is breathtaking , and his exquisite handling of the consequently - pivotal interior mise - en - scene makes for captivating viewing . lino ventura is superb as usual , succeeding to legitimize a character that , on paper , is cliche : the laconic , hard - nosed , world - weary homicide detective . ventura lives the role , making it abundantly believable , even though the script allows us little accessing to his inner workings ; the film ends at the very moment it appears he will be forced to confronting his failure for the first time . michel serrault is equal to the task as the suspected enfant - killer who shrewdly spars with the single - minded flic . the exchanges between the two are more - often - than - not pregnant with tension and the aura of a permanently metamorphosing playing field for a battle of wits . serrault ' s character is by turns deplorably haughty and cunning , and pitiable ; then later .... the " message " of garde a vue , if one were to search for one , is a condemnation of police methodology and the kind of pressures that make a cop over - zealous to , if necessary , close cases at the expense of justice . for most of its length though the film shines as nothing more than an exemplar of how to turn a potentially soporific set - bound scenario into a suspenseful drama of the utmost cinematic economy .--director

nothing revolutionary here ; just impeccably graceful , restrained cinema . garde a vue is confined almost exclusively to a drab police station , and mostly to one interrogation room , but director claude miller ( who made the marvellous film this sweet sickness , among others ) intercalates spare glimpses of exterior tableaux as minimalist locale scenography . miller ' s restraint , especially early on , is breathtaking , and his exquisite handling of the accordingly - vital interior mise - en - scene makes for captivating viewing . lino ventura is gorgeous as usual , succeeding to legitimize a character that , on paper , is cliche : the laconic , hard - nosed , world - weary homicide detective . ventura lives the role , making it totally believable , even though the script allows us little access to his inner workings ; the film ends at the very moment it appears he will be forced to confront his failure for the first time . michel serrault is equal to the task as the suspected child - killer who shrewdly spars with the single - minded flic . the shares between the two are more - frequently - than - not pregnant with tension and the aura of a constantly metamorphosing playing field for a battle of wits . serrault ' s character is by turns deplorably haughty and cunning , and pitiable ; subsequently later .... the " message " of garde a vue , if one were to search for one , is a condemnation of police methodology and the kind of pressures that make a cop over - zealous to , if necessary , close cases at the expense of justice . for most of its length though the film shines as nothing more than an exemplar of how to turn a potentially soporific set - bound scenario into a suspenseful drama of the utmost cinematic economy .--director
as jack nicholson ' s directorial debut , drive , he say displays at the least that he is a gifted director of actors . even when the story might seem to lose its way to the audience ( and to a modern audience - if they can find it , which pops up now and again on ebay - it might seem more free formed than they think ), the film contains vivid , interesting characterizations . the film tells of two college kids : the protagonist is hector ( william tepper , in what borders on a break - out performance ), a star of the leopards , the college basketball team he plays on . while he has to deal with a coach ( bruce dern ) who puts on the pressure to stay focused , and a on and off girlfriend ( karen black ) with her own emotional problems , there ' s gabriel ( michael margotta ), the other kid . gabriel , it seems , is just a little more than freaked out by the possibility to be drafted , and so in his own radical mind - state he does what he can to keep out . but as hector try to find the balance between his oncoming renown and those he love , gabriel is going over the threshold of sanity . nicholson , on the technical side of things , displays a fascinating editing style that keeps things on edge during the basketball scenes , and implements darkness in many other scenes with a documentary - feel throughout . and from tepper , black , and even robert towne ( writer of chinatown , last detail , and missions : impossible among others , who rarely acts ) he garners some credible acting work . though in tepper there is a tendency to downplay his emotions . in some scenes , for example , when he could act brilliantly sarcastic , he doesn ' t play it for what it ' s worth . from margotta , on the other hand , there is a spirited , twisted force in his performance , and as he descends it ' s frightening , but perhaps understandable from the times ( and what a climax ). dern steals most of his scenes , by the way , in a performance that should have garnered him an oscar nomination . every line of his dialog is appropriate , veritable , and it ' s never hammed up like in recent coach movie performances . but what drags down the film is that elements involving the personages aren ' t explained to the degree one might wish more . the film was based on a novel by jeremy larner , who co - wrote the script with nicholson , and i was expecting that the film to be longer than it was . it ' s a slim volume with a lot of information , about the times , about the sport , about the underlying feelings that were with those of the younger generation . nicholson presents us with these characters and situations , and rarely are they shown to what ' s motivating them ( the anti - war protesters not included , their part ' s understandable enough ). gabriel is perturbed by what ' s going on in vietnam , but what else is there ? hector , too , is a bloke who has apprehensions about being drafted for the nba , and he still loves to play , but what ' s holding him back ? this whole atmosphere is intriguing , how the late 60 ' s universities / basketball experience was , but that intriguing quality , which does lead to some unconventionality , is kept at a point where it can ' t go too further . overall , the effect of the film as a whole is bittersweet , and somewhat memorable for its good points , and not for it ' s low ones . and , for sure , you can tell who ' s behind the lens every step of the way . b +--girlfriend

the first time my best friend and i sat down to watch this movie , we were watching it for alex winter of " billing & ted ' s " fame . we didn ' t know what to expect other than who and what it was about . by the time the movie was over , we knew that it was love at first vision . this movie , while not totally historically accurate , was and is the best one of its genre . i have seen other movies depicting the history of this famous summer and in my opinion , none of the others can compare . it fibbed a little at certain details , but those parts did not take away from the sheer elegance and romance of the story . i have seen the other movies about this summer and i find most of them to be good , but none as captivating as this one . " haunted summer " has the qualities of a painting . the colors and settings seem to be somethings one would find on a canvas , framed and hung in a museum or on the walls of an eccentric ' s home . the costumes were gorgeous and , despite not being the most comfortable clothes in the world , made me want to find a seamstress to create such garb for myself . the whole movie was set on the picturesque lake geneva ( where i hope to one day go because of seeing this movie ) and the serenity that these historical figures found there . this movie shows , besides the tranquility found by all the escapees of england ' s harsh judgements , the strangeness that surrounded this adventure as well . yes , there were drugs . it was a fairly common practice during that time , a time when drugs were not illegal . and the taking of laudanum ( the liquid form of opium ) was medicinal as well as recreational . shelley suffered from consumption . lord byron suffered the pains of a clubbed foot . it was not stunning that there would be prescriptions of the strong drugs that were in their possession during that summer . and they were poets during a time when experience was the key . there was no time for prudish caution . passion and experience were a big part of the romantic era . and out of the thoughts and discussions of science , religious and philosophy came the creation of a legend : " frankenstein . " yes , in this movie , we see the beautiful and liberated mary godwin ( not married to shelley at that time ) played by beautiful and talented alice krige . she is the control factor to all that goes on until she , too , gives in to experience . but she stands her ground and experiences things on her own terms . as was the strength that she inherited from her mother and father . the actors and actresses in this were irreproachable for the parts they played . the music fitting . the direction capture the essence of the summer , as i ' ve read about it . this movie was based on a awesome book " haunted summer " by anne edwards . if you like this movie , read the book . the author takes the story from what she was able to put together from the actual journals of mary godwin shelley and the other participants of this story . if you are a person who loves history ( even the little inaccuracies from time to time ) and romance and the gothic , then this is a movie for you . it shows the birth of the birth of the monster , which even today teaches us about the morals of " playing god . " a definite must see movie !--friend

" haunted summer " has the qualities of a painting . the colors and settings seem to be something one would find on a canvas , framed and hung in a museum or on the walls of an eccentric ' s home . the costumes were fantastic and , despite not being the most comfortable clothes in the world , made me want to find a seamstress to create such garb for myself . the whole movie was set on the picturesque lake geneva ( where i hope to one day go because of seeing this movie ) and the serenity that these historical figures found there . this movie shows , besides the tranquility found by all the escapees of england ' s harsh judgements , the strangeness that surrounded this adventure as well . yes , there were drugs . it was a fairly common practice during that time , a time when drugs were not illegal . and the taking of laudanum ( the liquid form of opium ) was medicinal as well as recreational . shelley suffered from consumption . seigneur byron suffered the pains of a clubbed foot . it was not surprising that there would be prescriptions of the strong drugs that were in their possession during that summer . and they were poets during a time when experience was the vital . there was no time for prudish caution . passion and experience were a large part of the romantic era . and out of the thoughts and discussions of science , religion and philosophy came the creation of a legend : " frankenstein . " a definite must see movie !--friend
this is a frank loesser masterpiece of fun lyrics , competent themes and solid construction by those who adapted damon runyon material to the musical ' s " book ". what is surprising about the film is how seamlessly the musical numbers flow from the storyline . abe burrows did the book with contributions from loesser ; michael kidd was the choreographer , and the outstanding art direction was contributed by joseph wright . the storyline can be told in two sentences . nathan detroit , played by frank sinatra , needs cash to finance his permanent floating crap game to amuse big julie , a chicago mob boss . he bets odds - player sky masterson , well - presented by marlon brando , that he cannot get a salvation army girl to go to havana with him ; masterson wins the bet , saves the mission , falls in love with the girl , gets the gamblers and riffraff at the crap game to attend a service , and tells everybody the lady was impervious to his charms -- a finishing lie . of course he ends up with the lady ; and detroit marries hi long - suffering fiancée , vivian blaine . others in the cast include stubby kaye , johnny silver , robert keith , b . s . pulley as big julie the mobster , sheldon leonard , regis toomey , mary alan kokanson , kathryn givney as the salvation army leader , veda ann borg and jean simmons as the tepid salvation army girl , sarah brown . the famous musical numbers in this award - winning broadway smash include " fugue for tinhorns ", " guys and dolls ", " chance be a lady ", " i ' ll know ", " a person could develop a cold ", and " the oldest established permnanet floating crap game in new york !". joseph l . mankiewicz of " cleopatra " and " letter to three wives " fame directed the proceedings ; and the flow of the working is very interestingly and successfully kept moving . he is equally adept at getting fine dialogue acting and directing such huge numerals as " luck be lady ", the differs and challenging brawl section , the havana " a woman in love " section created for the film that precedes it , the presenting of the title song " guys and dolls " and " pet me , poppa " set in the club where blaine works . the acting is very uneven . simmons seems wrong for the part at times , brando gets by with the singing and is very good much of the time on instinct , charm and underplaying , even in the comedy . scenes . sinatra tries hard but is wrong for the role for several reasons as nathan detroit ; blaine is a bit too - theatrical in selling her numbers , which she of course sings professionally . leonard , toomey , kaye , keith and pulley do what is asked and more at all points . the stylized opening and closing are made to work well ; all in all , this film is a triumph for loesser ' s friendly and subtle lyrics , for director mankiewicz as ringmaster , and for the genre of musicals itself , so ably justified in this instance . delightful and very diverse .--leader
loved it but still have nightmares over the hotel manager . the movie , was presented well , with the opting of actors carrying their roles to reality of the writing . many scenes gripped the imagination and created a nail biter . the progress of circumstances were cleverly written , making me believe the story was headed one way only to find a new twist on what i thought might be the apparent . too bad there have to be commercials . i have told many friends to watch for further showings and i of course will opinion again . i enjoyed the scenery of the film and felt this added to the plots and intrigue . husband and wife heated discussions ( or should i say fighting ?) were very pragmatic . the initial situation is a common one but the escalation into the stories presented fortunately is not . i want to thank all who were involved in this great amusement film . gratitude you ! looking forward to the next films --- when ? whidbey--manager

after seeing this film at the sf independent film festival , i couldn ' t wait to hear about how to get a copy . jim mckay gave a talk ( q & a ) about the film afterward which presented his ironic situation : how to get distribution for a film which portrays minorities ( women , non - whites ) working on resolving controversial issues ( teen pregnancy , adolescence maternity , racial identity , single - mum household ), and how to write a faithful script on all of these topics being a mid - thirties white male . the multi - racial , multi - gendered audience of mostly - adults raved about the film ' s beautiful storyline , detailed characters , and resplendent portrayal of " real teen life ." most of the teens , however , had left the building -- leading me to think this is a film best seen by adults with kids , as a starting point for discussion rather than , as many adults there felt , " a film teens should see because it ' s roughly them ." hence , distribution questions -- how do we get our hands on it ? the internet ( retail ) would be a great path -- this is a film that will be buried , like " pups " or other radical modern adolescent films -- and mckay seemed responsive . as for his credits as a writer / director , mckay was _extremeley_ sensitive and detailed in his work -- allying himself to the crown heights neighborhood in which the film is set , work with actors to portray characters in their own vision of what they think should be -- with the results being disarmingly realistic .--director

after seeing this film at the sf independent film festival , i couldn ' t wait to hear about how to get a copy . jim mckay gave a talk ( q & a ) about the film afterward which presented his ironic situation : how to get distribution for a film which portrays minorities ( women , non - whites ) working on resolving controversial issues ( teen pregnancy , teen motherhood , racial identity , single - mother households ), and how to write a faithful script on all of these topics being a mid - thirties white male . the multi - racial , multi - gendered audience of principally - adults raved about the film ' s fantastic storyline , detailed characters , and fantastic portrayal of " real teen life ." most of the youngsters , however , had left the building -- leading me to think this is a film best seen by adults with kids , as a commencing point for discussion rather than , as many adults there felt , " a film teenager should see because it ' s approximately them ." hence , distribution questions -- how do we get our hands on it ? the internet ( retail ) would be a great path -- this is a film that will be buried , like " pups " or other radical modern teen films -- and mckay seemed responsive . as for his credits as a writer / director , mckay was _extremeley_ sensitive and detailed in his work -- allying himself to the crown heights neighborhood in which the film is set , working with actors to portray characters in their own sight of what they think ought be -- with the results underway disarmingly realistic .--director
a bit quirky and bordering bad taste ; but smarter enough to be worthy of watching . a wheelchair - bound young woman jane hatchard ( helena bonham carter ) is teamed with a reluctant caregiver , richard ( kenneth branagh ). richard is an artist that daydreams of human flight . he builds an airplane in his garage and intends to fly it . he wants to reanimate his own troubled life by taking care of the independent , dying jane , who suffers from an neurological sickness that has all but left her muted and very little car skills . wheelchair - bound and full of spirit , her last dying wish is to loose her virginity . she offers herself to richard , who won ' t support her directly ; but is willing to rob a bank in order to salary a gigolo to do the deed . i found this flick ambitious and humorous . even in this role , carter has a certain charisma and likability .--artist
